turns.content:
Generate in form of api documentation 
1. To receive a token a wallet has to be generated, 
the endpoint is = POST /account/wallet 
the parameters are token, coin and network. 
eg token: user token to accessthe api, , coin=BTC , network=BTC. 
resposes are : address, memo and network,coin

API Documentation: Generate Wallet Endpoint

Endpoint: POST /account/wallet

Description:
This endpoint generates a wallet for a user with the specified coin and network. A wallet address and memo will be returned upon successful creation.

Request Parameters:

* token (required): User token to access the API.
* coin (required): The cryptocurrency to generate the wallet for. Supported coins: BTC, ETH, LTC.
* network (required): The network to generate the wallet for. Supported networks: BTC, ETH, LTC.

Example Request:
```bash
POST /account/wallet
{
  "token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9",
  "coin": "BTC",
  "network": "BTC"
}
```
Example Response:
```css
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
{
  "address": "1BvBMSEYstWetqTFn5Au4m4GFg7xJaNVN2",
  "memo": "abc123",
  "network": "BTC",
  "coin": "BTC"
}
```
Response Fields:

* address: The generated wallet address.
* memo: A memo or tag associated with the wallet (optional).
* network: The network the wallet was generated for.
* coin: The cryptocurrency the wallet was generated for.

Error Responses:

* HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request: Invalid or missing request parameters.
* HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized: Invalid or expired user token.
* HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error: An error occurred on the server while processing the request.

you can get alist of network you can use from market data endpoint 
results all assets has an array of networks you can use
endpoint is GET /general/market\_data response example is is 
 "name": "Bitcoin",
 "coin": "BTC",
 "\_24hrs": "1.046",
 "network": [
 {
 "id": 4060,
 "coin": "BTC",
 "network": "BNB",
 "name": "Binance Chain (BEP2)",
 },
 
 ]

API Documentation: Market Data Endpoint

Endpoint: GET /general/market\_data

Description:
This endpoint returns market data for supported cryptocurrencies, including a list of networks that can be used for each coin.

Request Parameters: None

Example Request:
```bash
GET /general/market_data
```
Example Response:
```css
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
[  {    "name": "Bitcoin",    "coin": "BTC",    "_24hrs": "1.046",    "network": [      {        "id": 4060,        "coin": "BTC",        "network": "BNB",        "name": "Binance Chain (BEP2)"      },      {        "id": 157,        "coin": "BTC",        "network": "BCH",        "name": "Bitcoin Cash"      },      {        "id": 175,        "coin": "BTC",        "network": "BSV",        "name": "Bitcoin SV"      },      ...    ]
  },
  ...
]
```
Response Fields:

* name: The name of the cryptocurrency.
* coin: The symbol or code of the cryptocurrency.
* \_24hrs: The percentage change in price over the last 24 hours.
* network: An array of networks that can be used with the cryptocurrency. Each network object contains the following fields:
	+ id: The unique identifier of the network.
	+ coin: The symbol or code of the cryptocurrency.
	+ network: The symbol or code of the network.
	+ name: The name of the network.

Error Responses:

* HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error: An error occurred on the server while processing the request.

To send a token u will need to firstly get the breaakdown this will show the fee charged and the amount 
the user will received if it send the token. 
 the endpoint is /account/trade\_breakdown , is a post request , 
 params are token: user token to access, type="withdraw", 
 amount="amount of token to send out" , asset = the name of the coin , network = the network response are 
 assetUnits: number;
 withdrawFee: number;

 seconly send a confirmation OTP email to user email before you submit it
the endpoint is POST /account/withdrawal\_otp
the params are asset\_units, address, memo, asset, asset\_units: is the amount of token token sending out e.g 0.00045
address; the recipient address, memo= optional but if the network of the coin selected has a memoRegex as a value u will need to provide it 
while asset is the name of the token sending out eg BTC

 thirdly, is to send a token out
 the endpoint is /account/send\_token , is a post request , 
 params are token: user token to access, 
 amount="50" , 
 asset =USDT ,
 network = TRX,
 address=TNesdhhhsiiiiiieggelins
memo= optional but if the network of the coin selected has a memoRegex as a value u will need to provide 
otp= is the code received by the user in step 2

 this.response.data = {
 amount: `the amount of token user will received`,
 asset,
 address,
 memo,
 description=Your payment has been sent to address
 };

API Documentation: Send Token Endpoint

Endpoint: POST /account/trade\_breakdown

Description:
This endpoint calculates the trade breakdown for sending a token, including the fee charged and the amount the user will receive if they send the token.

Request Parameters:

* token: The user token to access the API.
* type: The type of trade, set to "withdraw".
* amount: The amount of the token to send out.
* asset: The symbol or code of the token.
* network: The symbol or code of the network.

Example Request:
```bash
POST /account/trade_breakdown
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {user_token}

{
  "type": "withdraw",
  "amount": "1.5",
  "asset": "BTC",
  "network": "BTC"
}
```
Example Response:
```json
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
{
  "assetUnits": 1.49998784,
  "withdrawFee": 0.00001216
}
```
Response Fields:

* assetUnits: The amount of the token the user will receive if they send the specified amount.
* withdrawFee: The fee charged for sending the token.

Error Responses:

* HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized: The user token is invalid or expired.
* HTTP/1.1 422 Unprocessable Entity: The request parameters are invalid or missing.

Endpoint: POST /account/withdrawal\_otp

Description:
This endpoint sends an OTP confirmation email to the user's email address.

Request Parameters:

* asset\_units: The amount of the token to send out.
* address: The recipient address.
* memo: Optional, but required if the network of the token selected has a memoRegex value.
* asset: The symbol or code of the token.

Example Request:
```bash
POST /account/withdrawal_otp
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {user_token}

{
  "asset_units": "1.5",
  "asset": "BTC",
  "address": "1A1zP1eP5QGefi2DMPTfTL5SLmv7DivfNa"
}
```
Example Response:
```css
HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
```
Error Responses:

* HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized: The user token is invalid or expired.
* HTTP/1.1 422 Unprocessable Entity: The request parameters are invalid or missing.

Endpoint: POST /account/send\_token

Description:
This endpoint sends the specified amount of tokens to the recipient address.

Request Parameters:

* token: The user token to access the API.
* amount: The amount of the token to send.
* asset: The symbol or code of the token.
* network: The symbol or code of the network.
* address: The recipient address.
* memo: Optional, but required if the network of the token selected has a memoRegex value.
* otp: The OTP code received by the user.

Example Request:
```bash
POST /account/send_token
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {user_token}

{
  "amount": "1.5",
  "asset": "BTC",
  "network": "BTC",
  "address": "1A1zP1eP5QGefi2DMPTfTL5SLmv7DivfNa",
  "otp": "123456"
}
```
Example Response:
```json
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
{
  "amount": "1.5",
  "asset": "BTC",
  "address": "1A1zP1eP5QGefi2DMPTfTL5SLmv7DivfNa
```
